text: when I first started to learn web
development I paid $400 for a CD of
Adobe Dreamweaver unlike the text
editors we use today what you see is
what you get wizzy wigs have been around
forever Visual Basic for Windows came
out 30 years ago game developers write
code by dragging and dropping in tools
like unreal and mobile IDs like Android
Studio always keep the UI by your side
but on the web we choose to write most
of our code with a blindfold on I think
this is due to the challenge of
responsive design during the browser
Wars but those days are mostly behind us
in today's video we'll build an image
Carousel inspired by airbnb's website
using a new visual IDE called codex
created by Wix the sponsor of this video
that brings drag and drop productivity
to react apps as a stubborn web
developer myself I was a bit skeptical
to try it but what I found is that it
can dramatically simplify certain jobs
and does so in a non-invasive way one
thing I've always hated about visual
tools is they tend to create code that
you don't understand but that's not the
case with codex it works in tandem with
VSS code while providing a robust visual
layer on top of your code it'll be
easier if I just show you so let's take
a look at what we're building today we
have a collection of cards for various
airbnbs which are made responsive with
CSS grid each card has its own
collection of images which can be
rotated through by clicking this button
nothing too crazy but the way we'll
build this is like nothing you've ever
seen before when it comes to react
development the first step is to
download it from the website and it's
entirely free by the way then create a
new project you have the option to
import an existing project the only
requirement is that it uses typescript
and either CSS module SAS or styleable
for your styling the main thing I don't
like about this editor is that it only
supports react I would love a tool like
this for spelt view angular and so on in
any case I'm going to start from scratch
and go with the built-in V template
after it creates and installs the
dependencies you'll notice it creates a
board a board is just a component itself
that allows you to isolate your own
components very similar to a tool like
storybook if we go ahead and click on a
board that'll bring us into the main
editor down here at the bottom it
contains the code for that board again
it's just a component that in this case
renders the app component there's a lot
to talk about here but first I want to
back up back on the Home tab you'll
notice a few other icons here in the
bottom left corner like the file
explorer to look at the actual files in
this project which can be edited just
like you would in VSS code with syntax
highlighting and code completion and
then you also have a full git
integration as well where you can easily
make and revert commits as needed what's
important to understand though is that
this is not trying to be a replacement
for vs code but rather it complements it
if we go back into the board you'll
notice this little menu here next to the
component that allows us to open it
directly in VSS code looking closer at
the file structure you'll notice a
folder named codex this contains any
boards or templates that aren't part of
your main application there's also a
codex config file that can modify Its
Behavior but the cool thing is that
anything you edit in the project in vs
code will be instantly reflected in
codex as you can see here I've got the
app component open but I want to get rid
of all this boiler plate as I go through
and delete elements and save the file
it's instantly updated in the Codex UI
but here's where things start to get fun
if we go into codex and click on a
component it brings up the editor which
gives us a hierarchy of elements in the
Dom if we click on when its bounding box
is highlighted in the UI which is useful
but we can also add new elements to the
Dom by clicking the add button and that
brings us an entire list of all the
possibilities personally I find this
extremely useful for building complex
forms because we can just drag and drop
all the form elements we need and
rearrange them which is far more
efficient than trying to do that in code
no matter how good you are in Vim then
on the other side of the screen
properties on any element can be
modified we can easily filter and update
them here and it will modify the code
automatically that's pretty cool but now
it's time to build our first react
component back in the home screen I'll
go ahead and click add followed by new
component we'll give it a name of BNB
card which will represent our image
Carousel it's also worth noting that you
can create custom templates if you find
yourself implementing the same patterns
in multiple components once created
you'll notice back in the Home tab that
it also creates a new board for us which
allows us to develop this component in
isolation now go to the component and
click the pencil icon to bring up its
code notice how we have a typescript
interface here called BNB card props
when we add props to the interface we
can automatically start using them in
codex from the properties panel and
that's why it's required to use
typescript when using codex for each one
of these cards we'll need a title a
price and an array of image URLs now go
back to the board and click on that
component and we can modify its props
right here to give it some dummy data to
build this card we'll first structure
out its elements delete the default text
then drop in a div below the root
that'll be our main card then inside
that div we have two other divs the
first one for the Carousel and the
second one for the main content below
the images now in the top div we can add
a dummy image for now and then in the
bottom div we can drag in a heading as
well as a paragraph and then we can
rearrange these elements as needed by
simply dragging and dropping and just
like that we have a basic card but it's
lacking in style luckily codex has an
awesome style editor which might be my
favorite feature of all go ahead and
click on the outer div then on the right
side you'll see a couple of other icons
computed Styles will give you a
breakdown of all the styles that
currently apply to that element this is
huge because I always find myself going
back and forth in the browser Dev tools
to look at computed Styles it's
extremely convenient to have this
information directly in your IDE now
click on the paintbrush to go to the
style editor click plus to add a new
class to this div and give it a name of
card that will add the card class to our
chosen CSS module and also apply it to
the div in the code then the CSS Editor
is amazing we can filter any CSS
property if we know what its name is or
we can go down here and do everything
visually like I'll go ahead and make it
a flex box make it flow vertically set
the Overflow to Hidden and set a Max
width of 300 pixels that's convenient
but it also has some pretty Advanced
tools built into the editor like when it
comes to Shadows the shadow editor
allows you to change all the various
properties which is extremely difficult
and tedious to do in code but now it's
time to make this component interactive
back in the elements panel I'm going to
add another div inside the carousel
along with a couple of buttons inside of
it when pressed these buttons should
rotate between the images in the
carousel we could write all this code
and codex but at this point you may
prefer to switch over to vs code we'll
first destructure the props from our
interface and then use that to
interpolate Dynamic data like the title
and the price from there we can add some
State for the current index of the image
that we want to show in the carousel
after which we can define a couple of
functions like previous image and next
image to change the index in a specific
Direction now let's go ahead and stop
there and go back to codex if we look at
the component you can now see it's using
our Dynamic data that we created earlier
and if you look in the elements tab
you'll see a gray icon here that tells
us it's an expression or a value
computed in the react jsx code but one
thing we forgot to do in our code is
bind our Carousel functions to the
buttons select a button from the
elements tab then go to the properties
panel and find the onclick property
check that box and it will add an
onclick event handler to that button
then all we have to do is go down to the
code and add the appropriate function
name then the final step is to update
the default image with the current index
of the images array at this point click
on the eyeball to preview the app here
in codex and it should toggle between
images in the carousel but now that we
have a working component we can put it
to use in other places in the
application for example if we go back to
the app board we can now drag and drop
our custom component there it shows an
error initially because it's missing the
required props in my full demo I took
some dummy data and looped over it to
show multiple carousels and then styled
them with CSS grid here in codex the
cool thing about this is I can change
the size of the canvas to check its
responsiveness without ever having to
leave the IDE overall codex is a very
new tool and won't replace your main
editor but it has some features that I
think really any developer could take
advantage of whether you're a beginner
or highly experienced but I'm curious to
know what you guys think let me know if
this is a tool you would actually use in
the comments thanks for watching and I
will see you in the next one
